title: The teenage brain
intro: We look inside the teenage brain and find out what's going. Neil and Rob discuss how this important organ affects the way young people behave and there'll be some brain-related vocabulary to learn.
this_week_question: What part of the brain is connected with basic emotions? Is it the…
a) prefrontal cortex? b) cerebral cortex? c) limbic sytem?

vocab.desc: a jumper or sweatshirt that has a hood on it
a period of time children have to stay at school after classes have finished as a punishment
natural chemicals produced in animals that control how they develop and grow
time period in life when a person changes into an adult

vocab.text: get a kick out of something

vocab.desc: part of the brain that encourages young people to take risks
part of the brain that encourages a young person to slow down
target of someone's joke/made fun of
copy someone's style in an exaggerated way
to talk about someone/something to make people believe they are/it is evil or threatening

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Rob … and I'm Rob. Hello.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Neil Hello, Rob. I like your new hoody.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh, right! Thanks a lot. A hoody is a sweatshirt with a hood, by the way. You don't think I'm too old for hoodies, do you?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Never. No, no. You too old? Never, Rob! It’s all about how young you feel inside, isn't it?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Is that right? Well, I don’t feel a day over sixteen, Neil.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Excellent! Now, that might help you because in this programme we’re talking about the teenage brain! So, are you ready for today's quiz question, Rob?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes, I am Neil. Fire away.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK. What part of the brain is connected with basic emotions? Is it the…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. I was terrible at biology – I never listened in class. So I'm going to have to take a guess and say the answer is a) prefrontal cortex.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, well. We’ll find out if that’s the right answer at the end of the programme. Now Rob, were you a well-behaved student?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, I wasn't badly behaved. But we had a horrible school uniform and sometimes I got detention just for having my shirt hanging out.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's pretty harsh! Detention means having to stay at school after the day to do extra work.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes it was a punishment for doing something wrong. Now some people think that typical teenage behaviour such as embarrassment, anxiety, mood swings and risk taking is caused by changing hormones.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Mood swings are sudden changes of mood and hormones are chemicals in the body that stimulate cells and organs into action.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Yes. I bet you were a moody teenager, Neil!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I might have been (in a teenage voice)… no, let's not go there, Rob. Now, apparently, it’s not only our hormones that change when we reach adolescence – that’s the age when we start changing into an adult.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's right. According to scientific research, some teenage behaviour is probably caused by changes in the brain. Let's listen to Professor Sarah-Jayne Blakemore talking about this. What's the phrase she uses to mean 'to enjoy'?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Sarah-Jayne Blakemore, Professor of Cognitive Neuroscience, University College London There's a pretty established theory of risk taking – the biological basis of risk taking – which is that two different systems in the brain developed at different rates. The parts of the brain called the limbic system, which includes the regions of the brain that give you a rewarding feeling out of taking a risk, a kind of kick out of taking a risk, and an emotion out of taking a risk, are developing more quickly than the part of the brain called the pre-frontal cortex, which inhibits risk taking.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So what risks do teenagers typically take?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well. The things most parents worry about, such as drinking, smoking, possibly taking drugs, and driving too fast.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And the reason that they take these risks might be because the area of the brain that rewards risk-taking behaviour develops more quickly than the area of the brain that inhibits – or slows down – risk-taking behaviour.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And what was the phrase she used to mean 'enjoy something'?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It was to get a kick out of something . Teenagers 'get a kick out of' and are rewarded for taking risks by one part of the brain – the limbic system – while the other part – the pre-frontal cortex – does little to slow things down.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, that sounds more fun than being an adult. But actually, we often give teenagers a hard time. Let's hear more about this from Sarah-Jayne.

transcript.author: Sarah-Jayne Blakemore, Professor of Cognitive Neuroscience at University College London
transcript.text: Something that I've noticed since working with teenagers is that they are the butt of many jokes. And they're parodied left, right and centre. They're demonized in newspapers. And whenever I tweet anything about the teenage brain – which I do quite frequently – invariably, inevitably, I'll get a reply from someone saying, 'Oh, what, teenagers actually have brains?'

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now of course some teenagers are very brainy – brainy is another way of saying clever. I know young people who are brilliant at maths, art and science.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But we heard Sarah-Jayne describe teenagers as being the butt of a joke – that means to be its target. And if you parody someone you copy their style in an exaggerated way to make people laugh.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And to demonize a person or a group means to talk about them as if they were evil or threatening. Poor teenagers, Rob!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Oh, don't worry, Neil – they'll grow up and be like us one day! And now it's time to hear the answer to today’s quiz question.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes it is. I asked you, what part of the brain is connected with basic emotions? Is it the… a) prefrontal cortex? b) cerebral cortex? or c) limbic system?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And I chose a) prefrontal cortex. Was I right?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well. I'm afraid to say, Rob, that you were absolutely wrong.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Using the wrong part of my brain, obviously.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. The answer is c) the limbic system. But don't get too emotional about getting that wrong and instead, please remind us of the words we learned today?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Good idea. We heard:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. I hope you got some kicks from today's show! You can hear more programmes at bbclearningenglish.com. Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.

authors: Sarah-Jayne Blakemore, Professor of Cognitive Neuroscience at University College London
